timeline.message: Refactor Boolean comparison with referential equality to equals-equality

timeline.bodyText: I see why we would keep this as != true (because it's possible we don't understand why the original programmer chose to do it this way, and we don't want to have unintended consequences), but I'm wondering if Boolean.FALSE.equals would be better. Minor detail and to me it doesn't require changes.
timeline.author: tiffca

replies.bodyText: Keep in mind that Boolean has 3 states. False, True and null
replies.author: krusche

replies.bodyText:
The reason why I chose to do it that way is that Boolean.FALSE.equals(null) is false but null != Boolean.TRUE and !Boolean.TRUE.equals(null) are both true. This is one of the pitfalls when dealing with the wrapper classes. But I do agree that the other variant is better readable.
Maybe we later need to look if that can be simplified or converted, it is however a change in semantics.
replies.author: MaisiKoleni
